Early Access Review
								Gnomoria doesn't just take time. It gobbles it up in huge chunks :PThe game is awesome, though. You get to manage a small (and growing) settlement, battling your way through hordes of goblins, golems, mants (yes, it's a thing) and much much more. Or not, if you prefer it quiet-like. You can micromanage or you can just set all your workshops to craft missing ingridients and have everybody automagically do stuff for you while you worry about the big picture.New players should definitely check out the wiki tutorial[www.gnomoriawiki.com] to get a good start as the first year is really hard to get through without some kind of strategy. Not that it gets easier after that, the trouble just changes character ;)If you like building/ defense games, this is awesome ^^

content:

Early Access Review
								I tried it out a long time ago and was impressed enough to buy it, especially for the price.It was great and worth its price a long time ago and now its even better. Never had a problem with frames per second myself, but the game is probably a little more demanding than it looks.I like that he's added things to the game that I wouldn't have expected like making a  private room decked out enough to attract better diplomats and being able to smelt crappy goblin weapons into fresh bars.It's also fairly challenging as the attacks on your home keep escalating.My only regret is that for some reason I really want to know what my Gnomes dreams/goals are and what they like/dislike about their new home so far. I want to know who their favorite Gnome is and maybe he/she gets appointed Governor-General  maybe? I also want them to be able to get married and have kids.It would be also cool if your Town influenced the world around you in a more detailed way, like maybe the Goblins stop messing with you and make peace or ,maybe a friendly Kingdom offers protection in exchange for exclusive trade rights? You know like the Gnome world is just SO impressed with your Gnome town.By saying that what I mean is I like the game enough to want even more from it.I feel weird saying that but it's an active little world with lots of jobs and skills that make the  Gnomes seem like they have more 'personality' than they realy do. I think it's called immersion.

								A Great Game!  There is plenty of content and lots to discover.  I have over 240+ hours and there is still more to do! A page on how to opt-in to that can be found it the LINKS section.Now to help ease one into the game without to many fallen kingdoms, I would recommend doing some research on the gameplay (in other words, READ SOME GUIDES).  Again, check the LINKS section for infoI mentioned a links section (like 20 times), so here it is!LINKS:   Site: http://gnomoria.com/    Forums: http://forums.gnomoria.com/index.php    Help: http://forums.gnomoria.com/index.php?board=4.0Roadmap: http://gnomoria.com/developer-plan/ My Kingdom: http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198087981854/screenshots/#scrollTop=0 How to Opt-In to Beta Branch http://forums.gnomoria.com/index.php?topic=6976.0    Guides: http://steamcommunity.com/app/224500/#scrollTop=0  http://forums.gnomoria.com/index.php?board=4.0 Gnomoria is simply a marvelous game, and I love it.  So what are you waiting for?  Go and get it!~Rchpweblo

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 19, 2015
Early Access Review
								One of the most addictive games i have ever played. Granted it took me a few tries to master the basics of the game, this couldn't be done in under an hour,  but once I had figured out to make my Gnomes most effective in their duties. Everything just fell in to place.   If the gnomes are not doing their duties, there is usually a reason for this and it is up to you to work out why!   I found that in early game it is best to create two crude work benches and have 2 gnomes assigned to them,  set one up to just create planks and nothing else,  do not accept other jobs and the second to make a few workbenches and chairs.  This way you have a few items ready in your stores to create the workshops you need quickly further along in the game once you have your little indoor area set out.  After this the next bench i would make would be a stonecutter (i think?),  the one who makes stone blocks,  and just have him continually make blocks on repeat with all the raw stone.  This again speeds up your processes if that is all he he doing.  The blocks are ready then to create whatever you need. e.g Tables, floors, statues etc.I loved getting new Gnomads at the beggining of a new season and growing my colony, there is much to be getting on with and the is much deeper than it first appears.  With animals to gain and tend to and factions to fight with or against or zombie virusus!.  Its a great go to game when i want to have a strategy game to play.   Recommended for those who love basebuilders, so much potential.

Early Access Review
								Absolutely recommended if you like Town-managing games. You control a small group of Gnomes at first and direct them to dig an underground-fortress to defend against the wild animals roaming the map or other evil creatures. You gather resrouces and process them into more refined buildingmaterials or commodities which can be traded with.The game can be boggling hard - but you can also finetune your worlds and disable any type of enemy down to a sandbox-type of game.The game features rather pixelated graphics and doesnt show any animations, safe for a bit of Flicker on the torches, but if you are looking for a simple time-waster in-between anything, this is your choice to run even on the oldest machines.Keep in mind though, that Gnomoria is not finished yet and games, for example, can start lagging. Save-Loading fixes temporarily fixes that, though.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								Gnomoria is a really fun game. It doesn't take too long to figure out the controls or how to play the game. There are lots of dangers your gnomes will face. Such as bears mauling your woodcutters, armored goblins attacking your gates or skeletons and spiders in your mines. There are lots of different materials your can build your base with. Like bones, stone, metal, wood and even dirt. There are lots of different colors aswell!Gnomoria still has quite a few bugs, which is to be expected since it's an early access game. Content is still being added to the game along with the bug fixes. Last updates added prosthetics (in case one of your gnomes loses an arm or leg) and golems (robotic slaves that do your bidding while fueled by coal).Pros+ Easy interface/controls to use and understand+ Lots of various materials to build with+ Several different types of hostile creatures+ Resource trading with foreign kingdoms+ Mods supportedCons- Bugs- End game demands a lot of resources from your pc (disabling beetle spawning helps)- Some aspects of the game might seems a bit simplistic compared to other sandbox gamesWith all that being said I still think Gnomoria was well worth the money I spent on it. I've had many hours of fun with it while watching my gnomes struggle to survive.

content:

								26NOV2014 - Ive owned it for roughly a week at the time of this review and Ive played 116hrs so I can officially really review it. Its basically a simple looking yet strangely addictive base building/ management game. Dont let the extremely simple graphics fool you, the game play and depth are definitely there. For a low cost, highly in depth game developed by a single programmer in mid stages of creation this game is a steal. Note: there are bugs and some crashes but you can set the game to auto save often to where you wont be hindered. One thing to note and I pray its fixed soon: when playing Im hitting this glitch where it lags uncontrollably and its killer. Once it starts your creation...your level is effectively ruined. I can never get it to stop once it starts. I believe it has to due with the gnome path finding. Other than this - this game is a ton of fun. Looking forward to future updates.

								An amazingly addicting game. I have sunk many hours into this game and am regularly tempted to pick it back up for another 20-30 hours. While this game is currently in early access it's a fully functional game and could easily be in full release at this point. The Dev is regularly updating, now working on larger less-frequent updates with bigger changes compared to regular small updates, with the option to play the in development versions if you want to keep your fix of new content regularly. The only drawback in the game at current is a lack of tutorial / instructions to get you started meaning reliance on the wiki until you work things out, and maybe the limited content once you have built up your town and economy...but that's when the survival kicks in.

								this review need only 3 words...THIS IS SPARTA!!!!.... okay maybe it needs more than 3 words but that very accurately describes my experie4nce with gnomoria so far, starting off with... straw and seeds and a few boxes and within 3 or 4 days or so get attacked by 3 goblins and watch my fierce little gnomes fight for their lives with little more than sticks with lumps of metal on the end vaguely shaped into tools, more often than not? the weak ones die right out leaving the strong to cobble together some sort of camp... and that was my first play,the only thing i can see is gnomes on a spartonian lifestyle living with next to nothing against impossible odds and with the right thinking and resourcefulness coming out on top.to top that off if you survive long enough you can get your hand son some lovely resources to really beef up your minio- i mean loyal workers and build a sizeable fort all while trying to balance security with the prescious prescious rum... wait... wrong franchise, i meant food and water not thinking about those can easily kill off all your slav- loyal workers very quicklyof course if you know what your doing you can gather together the basic resources fairly easy but that often makes the incoming attacks even harder and bring more gnomes... which only increases the number of resource you need to spend... you seeing the pattern yet? xDto summurise this review then in 4 words:I LOVE THIS GAMEcourse that leaves just one more thing left to decide... do i have my farms in or outside of my keep?all

Early Access Review
								Way more fun than I expected! Granted, maybe I initially started playing too early in development, and it took another friend who has this game - as well as a lot of experience with Dwarf Fortress - giving me a quick starting tutorial to get me going, but within minutes I was hooked, and haven't played anything else in more than a week! Highly recommended for anyone who thinks they might be a fan of what I can only describe as "Minecraft meets The Sims".

								It's messy and slow to start and needs better tutorial and the devs are slow in fixing obvious issues. But. It's fun. And it's fairly easy to get into. Just click on♥♥♥♥♥♥until it works is a great philosophy in this game. I made an underground village and mined a lot of different ore and then I lost half of my people in the mysterious "Vanishing on the 8th day" and then my oxen vanished and then I built brewery.It's a bitter-sweet accomplishment.

content:
Posted: October 7, 2014
Early Access Review
								Gnomoria doesn't just take time. It gobbles it up in huge chunks :PThe game is awesome, though. You get to manage a small (and growing) settlement, battling your way through hordes of goblins, golems, mants (yes, it's a thing) and much much more. Or not, if you prefer it quiet-like. You can micromanage or you can just set all your workshops to craft missing ingridients and have everybody automagically do stuff for you while you worry about the big picture.New players should definitely check out the wiki tutorial[www.gnomoriawiki.com] to get a good start as the first year is really hard to get through without some kind of strategy. Not that it gets easier after that, the trouble just changes character ;)If you like building/ defense games, this is awesome ^^

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								I tried it out a long time ago and was impressed enough to buy it, especially for the price.It was great and worth its price a long time ago and now its even better. Never had a problem with frames per second myself, but the game is probably a little more demanding than it looks.I like that he's added things to the game that I wouldn't have expected like making a  private room decked out enough to attract better diplomats and being able to smelt crappy goblin weapons into fresh bars.It's also fairly challenging as the attacks on your home keep escalating.My only regret is that for some reason I really want to know what my Gnomes dreams/goals are and what they like/dislike about their new home so far. I want to know who their favorite Gnome is and maybe he/she gets appointed Governor-General  maybe? I also want them to be able to get married and have kids.It would be also cool if your Town influenced the world around you in a more detailed way, like maybe the Goblins stop messing with you and make peace or ,maybe a friendly Kingdom offers protection in exchange for exclusive trade rights? You know like the Gnome world is just SO impressed with your Gnome town.By saying that what I mean is I like the game enough to want even more from it.I feel weird saying that but it's an active little world with lots of jobs and skills that make the  Gnomes seem like they have more 'personality' than they realy do. I think it's called immersion.
